$12.9 million (2008 USD) | total fatalities = 6 Injuries | area affected = [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland]] and [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]], [[New York]] and [[Fairfield County, Connecticut|Fairfield]], [[Connecticut]] }} The '''Westchester Tornado''' was an unusual [[Fujita_scale#Parameters|F2]] [[tornado]] that touched down in [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland New York]] on [[Tornadoes_of_2006#July_11-12|July 12, 2006]]. The tornado tracked for 13 [[mile|miles]] (20.9 [[kilometre|km]]) into southwestern [[Connecticut]] during a 33 minute span through two states. The tornado touched down at 3:30 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] (19:30 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]) on the shore of the [[Hudson River]] before becoming a [[waterspout]]. It tracked 3 mi (4.8 km) across the river before moving back over land. Coming ashore, the tornado struck the town [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow]] at F1 intensity. After passing through the town, it intensified into an F2 tornado and grew to almost a quarter mile in diameter. The tornado continued through the county causing damage to numerous structures along the way until it crossed into Connecticut at 4:01 p.m. EDT (20:01 UTC). Not long after entering the state, it lifted near the town of [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]] at 4:03 p.m. EDT (20:03 UTC). The tornado left considerable damage in its wake. Two barns and a warehouse were destroyed, a large stained-glass window was completely shattered. Numerous homes and businesses were damaged and thousands of trees were uprooted. No one was killed by the tornado and there were only six minor injuries associated with it. Total damages from the tornado totaled to $12.1 million (2006 [[United States Dollar|USD]]; $12.9 million 2008 USD). ==Meteorological synopsis== On July 12, a [[supercell]] [[thunderstorm]] developed over eastern [[New Jersey]] in association with a [[Low pressure area|surface low-pressure area]] in southwestern [[Ontario]]. Daytime heating in the [[Tri-State Region]] led to moderate instability, a key factor in the development of [[Atmospheric convection|showers and thunderstorms]]. With conditions favorable for the development of a [[tornado]], the [[Storm Prediction Center]] issued a [[tornado watch]] was issued at 12:40 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] (16:40 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]).{{cite web| author=Thompson| date=[[2006-07-12]]| title=Severe Weather Watch #593 (Tornado Watch)| publisher=[[Storm Prediction Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/products/watch/2006/ww0593.html}} At around 1:05 p.m. EDT (17:05 UTC), a thunderstorm produced winds up to 60 [[miles per hour|mph]] (95 [[kilometres per hour|km/h]]) in [[Warren County, New Jersey|Warren County]], which snapped tree limbs and damaged power lines.{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #625642 (Thunderstorm Wind)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~625642}} A stronger thunderstorm developed around 2 p.m. EDT (18:00 UTC) and produced a [[funnel cloud]] near [[Carlstadt, New Jersey|Carlstadt]] at around 2:45 p.m. EDT (18:45 UTC), no damage was associated with the funnel.{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #625643 (Funnel Cloud)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~625643}} That same storm became stronger and developed into a supercell thunderstorm as it crossed into [[New York]]. About 15 minutes later, a [[tornado warning]] was issued for southern Rockland and [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]] counties which would remain in effect until 4:15 p.m. (21:15 UTC). At around 3:30 p.m. EDT (19:30 UTC), an [[Fujita_scale#Parameters|F1]] tornado touched down near [[Grand View-on-Hudson, New York|Grand View-on-Hudson]] along the [[Hudson River]] in [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland County]]. The 100 [[yard]] (91 [[metre|m]]) wide tornado touched down on a dock before becoming a [[waterspout]] as it took a 3 [[mile|miles]] (4.8 [[kilometre|km]]) path across the river. The tornado passed near the [[Tappen Zee Bridge]] before crossing into [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester County]].{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #626587 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626587}} The tornado hit the town of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow, New York]] around 3:37 p.m. EDT (19:37 UTC), two minutes later, a 58 mph (93 km/h) wind gust was reported along the periphery of the tornado. As the tornado neared [[New York State Route 9A]], it intensified into an F2 tornado, packing winds up to 157 mph (253 km/h), and struck the California Closet Warehouse. At this time, the tornado was estimated to be 300 yd (274 m) wide and was the strongest tornado ever recorded in Westchester County.{{cite web| author=Jim Fitzgerald| date=2006-07-14| title=Weather Service confirms F-2 tornado roared through N.Y., Conn. on Wednesday| publisher=USA Today| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.usatoday.com/weather/storms/2006-07-14-ny-tornado-confirmed_x.htm}} Shortly after, the tornado weakened back to F1 intensity. Minor damage was reported through the [[Kensico Reservoir]] in [[Valhalla, New York|Valhalla]] as the tornado neared the New York/[[Connecticut]] border. The track length through Westchester County was measured at around 8 mi (12.8 km).{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #626588 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626588}} After crossing the border into [[Fairfield County, Connecticut]], the tornado weakened further before lifting at 4:03 p.m. EDT (20:03 UTC) in [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]] after traveling 2 mi (3.2 km) in Connecticut. Another brief touchdown may have occurred shortly after near the [[Merritt Parkway]].{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #606978 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~606978}} The tornado tracked across a total of 13 mi (20.9 km) through two states over a period over 33 minutes.{{cite web| date=2006-7-14| title=Summary of Tornado| publisher=[[National Weather Service]] in Upton, New York| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/okx/pns/torjul06.txt}} ==Impact== [[Image:DCP 7760.JPG|thumb|right|Tornado damage near a forested area]] The tornado took a clear path through [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland]], [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]], and [[Fairfield County, Connecticut|Fairfield]] counties, downing or uprooting thousands of trees, and damaging several structures, including significant structural damage to the California Closest Warehouse. Six minor injuries were also reported due to the tornado. In all, the tornado caused $12.1 million (2006 [[United States Dollar|USD]]; $12.9 million 2008 USD). Minor damage was reported in Rockland County. Only one structure, a dock, and one boat were damaged by the tornado. After crossing the [[Hudson River]], the tornado entered Westchester County, where the worst of the damage took place. The tornado first struck the town of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow]], damaging roofs and tearing the siding off of numerous homes and businesses. A 10 [[foot (length)|foot]] (3 [[metre|m]]) tall stained-glass window in the St. Teresa of Avila Church was shattered. Afterwards, the town of [[Pocantico Hills, New York|Pocantico Hills]] was struck as the tornado intensified to F2 intensity. Several trees were uprooted and two barns were destroyed. The California Closet Warehouse suffered severe structural damage, having two two-story concrete wall being destroyed. A interior staircase, which employees used as a shelter, collapsed, injuring four of them. Concrete blocks from the building were thrown all over, several cars in the nearby parking lot were hit by the blocks. A nearby Comfort Inn had part of its roof torn off.{{cite web| date=2006-7-13|author=Associated Press| title=Tornado Rips Through Suburban New York| publisher=Internet Broadcasting Systems, Inc.| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.wesh.com/news/9510358/detail.html}} After a [[tornado warning]] was issued, a school close to the warehouse was evacuated.{{cite web| author=Lisa W. Foderaro| date=2006-07-13| title=Tornado in Westchester Tosses Around Trees and Damages Property| publisher=New York Times| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/13/nyregion/13weather.html?pagewanted=print}} As the tornado crossed [[New York State Route 9A]], it picked up a state trooper car and flipped it a few times before it fell to the ground, the officer inside suffered only minor injuries. Moving to the east-northeast, the tornado struck the towns of [[Mount Pleasant, New York|Mount Pleasant]] and [[Hawthorne, New York|Hawthorne]], damaging numerous trees and causing minor structural damage. Damage along the [[Saw Mill River Parkway]] led officials to shut down a section of it near Mount Pleasant.{{cite web| author= Rose Arce | date=2006-07-13| title=Tornado hits north of Manhattan, Winds damage store, close highway; no serious injuries reported| publisher=Cable News Network.| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/WEATHER/07/12/ny.tornado/index.html }} Trees fell on streets and railroad tracks, halting [[Metro-North Railroad]] service and creating major traffic delays. After passing by the [[Kensico Reservoir]] in [[Valhalla, New York|Valhalla]], the tornado crossed into [[Connecticut]]. The tornado knocked down numerous power lines, cutting power to about 10,000 residences in the county. In all, six people sustained minor injuries and damages amounted to $10.1 million (2006 USD). The weakening tornado ended its life in Fairfield County, Connecticut near the town of [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]]. Thousands of trees were either uprooted or snapped along the 2 mi (3.2 km) path through the state. Minor damage was also reported to several structures. The tornado left 52 residences in Greenwich without power{{cite web| author=Eyewitness News| date=2006-07-13| title=Weather Service confirms F2 tornado in area, Sleepy Hollow, Hawthorne hardest hit| publisher=ABC News| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=weather&id=4363255}} and caused $2 million (2006 USD) in damages. ==Aftermath== In the wake of the tornado, the mayor of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York]] declared a state of emergency for the town. [[Consolidated Edison]] (conEdison) crews were sent out to repair downed power lines and clear roads. By the next night, power was restored to all but 600 of the previous 10,000 residences without power in [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]]. Westchester County opened its Emergency Operations Center after the storm to quickly respond to the event.{{cite web| author=Associated Press| date=2006-07-13| title=Westchester County Storm: Let The Clean-Up Begin| publisher=WCBS| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://wcbstv.com/topstories/Tornado.Tornado.Warning.2.236314.html}} Two days after the storm, many of the roads had been cleared and power was fully restored. A recreational path in [[Tarrytown, New York]] was not expected to be open for another two weeks due to numerous fallen trees.{{cite web| date=2006-7-15|author=Candice Ferrette| title=Westchester tornado twists many lives| publisher=Journal News| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.lohud.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060715/NEWS02/607150347}} [[Metro-North Railroad]] suspended trains on the Upper Harlem line until 5:00 p.m. EDT (21:00 UTC) for the removal of debris on the tracks. During the time the rails were shut down, southbound passengers were transported by bus. ==See also== *[[List of North American tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]] *[[Tornadoes of 2006]] *[[List of Connecticut tornadoes]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://wcbstv.com/video/?id=89570@wcbs.dayport.com Doppler Radar image of the tornadic supercell nearing Tarrytown] *[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_fLZLrZAB0M Video of the tornado damage in Westchester] *[http://wcbstv.com/topstories/Tornado.Tornado.Warning.2.236314.html WCBS article and video of damage/press reports of the tornado] Category:F2 tornadoes Category:New York tornadoes Category:Connecticut tornadoes Category:Tornadoes of 2006

It tracked 3 mi (4.8 km) across the river before moving back over land. Coming ashore, the tornado struck the town [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow]] at F1 intensity. After passing through the town, it intensified into an F2 tornado and grew to almost a quarter mile in diameter. The tornado continued through the county causing damage to numerous structures along the way until it crossed into Connecticut at 4:01 p.m. EDT (20:01 UTC). Not long after entering the state, it lifted near the town of [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]] at 4:03 p.m. EDT (20:03 UTC). The tornado left considerable damage in its wake. Two barns and a warehouse were destroyed, a large stained-glass window was completely shattered. Numerous homes and businesses were damaged and thousands of trees were uprooted. No one was killed by the tornado and there were only six minor injuries associated with it. Total damages from the tornado totaled to $12.1 million (2006 [[United States Dollar|USD]]; $12.9 million 2008 USD). ==Meteorological synopsis== On July 12, a [[supercell]] [[thunderstorm]] developed over eastern [[New Jersey]] in association with a [[Low pressure area|surface low-pressure area]] in southwestern [[Ontario]]. Daytime heating in the [[Tri-State Region]] led to moderate instability, a key factor in the development of [[Atmospheric convection|showers and thunderstorms]]. With conditions favorable for the development of a [[tornado]], the [[Storm Prediction Center]] issued a [[tornado watch]] was issued at 12:40 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] (16:40 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]).{{cite web| author=Thompson| date=[[2006-07-12]]| title=Severe Weather Watch #593 (Tornado Watch)| publisher=[[Storm Prediction Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/products/watch/2006/ww0593.html}} At around 1:05 p.m. EDT (17:05 UTC), a thunderstorm produced winds up to 60 [[miles per hour|mph]] (95 [[kilometres per hour|km/h]]) in [[Warren County, New Jersey|Warren County]], which snapped tree limbs and damaged power lines.{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #625642 (Thunderstorm Wind)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~625642}} A stronger thunderstorm developed around 2 p.m. EDT (18:00 UTC) and produced a [[funnel cloud]] near [[Carlstadt, New Jersey|Carlstadt]] at around 2:45 p.m. EDT (18:45 UTC), no damage was associated with the funnel.{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #625643 (Funnel Cloud)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~625643}} That same storm became stronger and developed into a supercell thunderstorm as it crossed into [[New York]]. About 15 minutes later, a [[tornado warning]] was issued for southern Rockland and [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]] counties which would remain in effect until 4:15 p.m. (21:15 UTC). At around 3:30 p.m. EDT (19:30 UTC), an [[Fujita_scale#Parameters|F1]] tornado touched down near [[Grand View-on-Hudson, New York|Grand View-on-Hudson]] along the [[Hudson River]] in [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland County]]. The 100 [[yard]] (91 [[metre|m]]) wide tornado touched down on a dock before becoming a [[waterspout]] as it took a 3 [[mile|miles]] (4.8 [[kilometre|km]]) path across the river. The tornado passed near the [[Tappen Zee Bridge]] before crossing into [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester County]].{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #626587 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626587}} The tornado hit the town of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow, New York]] around 3:37 p.m. EDT (19:37 UTC), two minutes later, a 58 mph (93 km/h) wind gust was reported along the periphery of the tornado. As the tornado neared [[New York State Route 9A]], it intensified into an F2 tornado, packing winds up to 157 mph (253 km/h), and struck the California Closet Warehouse. At this time, the tornado was estimated to be 300 yd (274 m) wide and was the strongest tornado ever recorded in Westchester County.{{cite web| author=Jim Fitzgerald| date=2006-07-14| title=Weather Service confirms F-2 tornado roared through N.Y., Conn. on Wednesday| publisher=USA Today| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.usatoday.com/weather/storms/2006-07-14-ny-tornado-confirmed_x.htm}} Shortly after, the tornado weakened back to F1 intensity. Minor damage was reported through the [[Kensico Reservoir]] in [[Valhalla, New York|Valhalla]] as the tornado neared the New York/[[Connecticut]] border. The track length through Westchester County was measured at around 8 mi (12.8 km).{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #626588 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626588}} After crossing the border into [[Fairfield County, Connecticut]], the tornado weakened further before lifting at 4:03 p.m. EDT (20:03 UTC) in [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]] after traveling 2 mi (3.2 km) in Connecticut. Another brief touchdown may have occurred shortly after near the [[Merritt Parkway]].{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #606978 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~606978}} The tornado tracked across a total of 13 mi (20.9 km) through two states over a period over 33 minutes.{{cite web| date=2006-7-14| title=Summary of Tornado| publisher=[[National Weather Service]] in Upton, New York| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/okx/pns/torjul06.txt}} ==Impact== [[Image:DCP 7760.JPG|thumb|right|Tornado damage near a forested area]] The tornado took a clear path through [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland]], [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]], and [[Fairfield County, Connecticut|Fairfield]] counties, downing or uprooting thousands of trees, and damaging several structures, including significant structural damage to the California Closest Warehouse. Six minor injuries were also reported due to the tornado. In all, the tornado caused $12.1 million (2006 [[United States Dollar|USD]]; $12.9 million 2008 USD). Minor damage was reported in Rockland County. Only one structure, a dock, and one boat were damaged by the tornado. After crossing the [[Hudson River]], the tornado entered Westchester County, where the worst of the damage took place. The tornado first struck the town of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow]], damaging roofs and tearing the siding off of numerous homes and businesses. A 10 [[foot (length)|foot]] (3 [[metre|m]]) tall stained-glass window in the St. Teresa of Avila Church was shattered. Afterwards, the town of [[Pocantico Hills, New York|Pocantico Hills]] was struck as the tornado intensified to F2 intensity. Several trees were uprooted and two barns were destroyed. The California Closet Warehouse suffered severe structural damage, having two two-story concrete wall being destroyed. A interior staircase, which employees used as a shelter, collapsed, injuring four of them. Concrete blocks from the building were thrown all over, several cars in the nearby parking lot were hit by the blocks. A nearby Comfort Inn had part of its roof torn off.{{cite web| date=2006-7-13|author=Associated Press| title=Tornado Rips Through Suburban New York| publisher=Internet Broadcasting Systems, Inc.| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.wesh.com/news/9510358/detail.html}} After a [[tornado warning]] was issued, a school close to the warehouse was evacuated.{{cite web| author=Lisa W. Foderaro| date=2006-07-13| title=Tornado in Westchester Tosses Around Trees and Damages Property| publisher=New York Times| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/13/nyregion/13weather.html?pagewanted=print}} As the tornado crossed [[New York State Route 9A]], it picked up a state trooper car and flipped it a few times before it fell to the ground, the officer inside suffered only minor injuries. Moving to the east-northeast, the tornado struck the towns of [[Mount Pleasant, New York|Mount Pleasant]] and [[Hawthorne, New York|Hawthorne]], damaging numerous trees and causing minor structural damage. Damage along the [[Saw Mill River Parkway]] led officials to shut down a section of it near Mount Pleasant.{{cite web| author= Rose Arce | date=2006-07-13| title=Tornado hits north of Manhattan, Winds damage store, close highway; no serious injuries reported| publisher=Cable News Network.| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/WEATHER/07/12/ny.tornado/index.html }} Trees fell on streets and railroad tracks, halting [[Metro-North Railroad]] service and creating major traffic delays. After passing by the [[Kensico Reservoir]] in [[Valhalla, New York|Valhalla]], the tornado crossed into [[Connecticut]]. The tornado knocked down numerous power lines, cutting power to about 10,000 residences in the county. In all, six people sustained minor injuries and damages amounted to $10.1 million (2006 USD). The weakening tornado ended its life in Fairfield County, Connecticut near the town of [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]]. Thousands of trees were either uprooted or snapped along the 2 mi (3.2 km) path through the state. Minor damage was also reported to several structures. The tornado left 52 residences in Greenwich without power{{cite web| author=Eyewitness News| date=2006-07-13| title=Weather Service confirms F2 tornado in area, Sleepy Hollow, Hawthorne hardest hit| publisher=ABC News| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=weather&id=4363255}} and caused $2 million (2006 USD) in damages. ==Aftermath== In the wake of the tornado, the mayor of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York]] declared a state of emergency for the town. [[Consolidated Edison]] (conEdison) crews were sent out to repair downed power lines and clear roads. By the next night, power was restored to all but 600 of the previous 10,000 residences without power in [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]]. Westchester County opened its Emergency Operations Center after the storm to quickly respond to the event.{{cite web| author=Associated Press| date=2006-07-13| title=Westchester County Storm: Let The Clean-Up Begin| publisher=WCBS| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://wcbstv.com/topstories/Tornado.Tornado.Warning.2.236314.html}} Two days after the storm, many of the roads had been cleared and power was fully restored. A recreational path in [[Tarrytown, New York]] was not expected to be open for another two weeks due to numerous fallen trees.{{cite web| date=2006-7-15|author=Candice Ferrette| title=Westchester tornado twists many lives| publisher=Journal News| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.lohud.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060715/NEWS02/607150347}} [[Metro-North Railroad]] suspended trains on the Upper Harlem line until 5:00 p.m. EDT (21:00 UTC) for the removal of debris on the tracks. During the time the rails were shut down, southbound passengers were transported by bus. ==See also== *[[List of North American tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]] *[[Tornadoes of 2006]] *[[List of Connecticut tornadoes]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://wcbstv.com/video/?id=89570@wcbs.dayport.com Doppler Radar image of the tornadic supercell nearing Tarrytown] *[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_fLZLrZAB0M Video of the tornado damage in Westchester] *[http://wcbstv.com/topstories/Tornado.Tornado.Warning.2.236314.html WCBS article and video of damage/press reports of the tornado] [[Category:F2 tornadoes]] [[Category:New York tornadoes]] [[Category:Connecticut tornadoes]] [[Category:Tornadoes of 2006]] [[Category:2006 in the United States]]

With conditions favorable for the development of a [[tornado]], the [[Storm Prediction Center]] issued a [[tornado watch]] was issued at 12:40 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] (16:40 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]).{{cite web| author=Thompson| date=[[2006-07-12]]| title=Severe Weather Watch #593 (Tornado Watch)| publisher=[[Storm Prediction Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/products/watch/2006/ww0593.html}} At around 1:05 p.m. EDT (17:05 UTC), a thunderstorm produced winds up to 60 [[miles per hour|mph]] (95 [[kilometres per hour|km/h]]) in [[Warren County, New Jersey|Warren County]], which snapped tree limbs and damaged power lines.{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #625642 (Thunderstorm Wind)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~625642}} A stronger thunderstorm developed around 2 p.m. EDT (18:00 UTC) and produced a [[funnel cloud]] near [[Carlstadt, New Jersey|Carlstadt]] at around 2:45 p.m. EDT (18:45 UTC), no damage was associated with the funnel.{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #625643 (Funnel Cloud)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~625643}} That same storm became stronger and developed into a supercell thunderstorm as it crossed into [[New York]]. About 15 minutes later, a [[tornado warning]] was issued for southern Rockland and [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]] counties which would remain in effect until 4:15 p.m. (21:15 UTC). At around 3:30 p.m. EDT (19:30 UTC), an [[Fujita_scale#Parameters|F1]] tornado touched down near [[Grand View-on-Hudson, New York|Grand View-on-Hudson]] along the [[Hudson River]] in [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland County]]. The 100 [[yard]] (91 [[metre|m]]) wide tornado touched down on a dock before becoming a [[waterspout]] as it took a 3 [[mile|miles]] (4.8 [[kilometre|km]]) path across the river. The tornado passed near the [[Tappan Zee Bridge]] before crossing into [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester County]].{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #626587 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626587}} The tornado hit the town of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow, New York]] around 3:37 p.m. EDT (19:37 UTC), two minutes later, a 58 mph (93 km/h) wind gust was reported along the periphery of the tornado. As the tornado neared [[New York State Route 9A]], it intensified into an F2 tornado, packing winds up to 157 mph (253 km/h), and struck the California Closet Warehouse. At this time, the tornado was estimated to be 300 yd (274 m) wide and was the strongest tornado ever recorded in Westchester County.{{cite web| author=Jim Fitzgerald| date=2006-07-14| title=Weather Service confirms F-2 tornado roared through N.Y., Conn. on Wednesday| publisher=USA Today| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.usatoday.com/weather/storms/2006-07-14-ny-tornado-confirmed_x.htm}} Shortly after, the tornado weakened back to F1 intensity. Minor damage was reported through the [[Kensico Reservoir]] in [[Valhalla, New York|Valhalla]] as the tornado neared the New York/[[Connecticut]] border. The track length through Westchester County was measured at around 8 mi (12.8 km).{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #626588 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626588}} After crossing the border into [[Fairfield County, Connecticut]], the tornado weakened further before lifting at 4:03 p.m. EDT (20:03 UTC) in [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]] after traveling 2 mi (3.2 km) in Connecticut. Another brief touchdown may have occurred shortly after near the [[Merritt Parkway]].{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #606978 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~606978}} The tornado tracked across a total of 13 mi (20.9 km) through two states over a period over 33 minutes.{{cite web| date=2006-7-14| title=Summary of Tornado| publisher=[[National Weather Service]] in Upton, New York| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/okx/pns/torjul06.txt}} ==Impact== [[Image:DCP 7760.JPG|thumb|right|Tornado damage near a forested area]] The tornado took a clear path through [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland]], [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]], and [[Fairfield County, Connecticut|Fairfield]] counties, downing or uprooting thousands of trees, and damaging several structures, including significant structural damage to the California Closest Warehouse. Six minor injuries were also reported due to the tornado. In all, the tornado caused $12.1 million (2006 [[United States Dollar|USD]]; $12.9 million 2008 USD). Minor damage was reported in Rockland County. Only one structure, a dock, and one boat were damaged by the tornado. After crossing the [[Hudson River]], the tornado entered Westchester County, where the worst of the damage took place. The tornado first struck the town of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow]], damaging roofs and tearing the siding off of numerous homes and businesses. A 10 [[foot (length)|foot]] (3 [[metre|m]]) tall stained-glass window in the St. Teresa of Avila Church was shattered. Afterwards, the town of [[Pocantico Hills, New York|Pocantico Hills]] was struck as the tornado intensified to F2 intensity. Several trees were uprooted and two barns were destroyed. The California Closet Warehouse suffered severe structural damage, having two two-story concrete wall being destroyed. A interior staircase, which employees used as a shelter, collapsed, injuring four of them. Concrete blocks from the building were thrown all over, several cars in the nearby parking lot were hit by the blocks. A nearby Comfort Inn had part of its roof torn off.{{cite web| date=2006-7-13|author=Associated Press| title=Tornado Rips Through Suburban New York| publisher=Internet Broadcasting Systems, Inc.| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.wesh.com/news/9510358/detail.html}} After a [[tornado warning]] was issued, a school close to the warehouse was evacuated.{{cite web| author=Lisa W. Foderaro| date=2006-07-13| title=Tornado in Westchester Tosses Around Trees and Damages Property| publisher=New York Times| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/13/nyregion/13weather.html?pagewanted=print}} As the tornado crossed [[New York State Route 9A]], it picked up a state trooper car and flipped it a few times before it fell to the ground, the officer inside suffered only minor injuries. Moving to the east-northeast, the tornado struck the towns of [[Mount Pleasant, New York|Mount Pleasant]] and [[Hawthorne, New York|Hawthorne]], damaging numerous trees and causing minor structural damage. Damage along the [[Saw Mill River Parkway]] led officials to shut down a section of it near Mount Pleasant.{{cite web| author= Rose Arce | date=2006-07-13| title=Tornado hits north of Manhattan, Winds damage store, close highway; no serious injuries reported| publisher=Cable News Network.| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/WEATHER/07/12/ny.tornado/index.html }} Trees fell on streets and railroad tracks, halting [[Metro-North Railroad]] service and creating major traffic delays. After passing by the [[Kensico Reservoir]] in [[Valhalla, New York|Valhalla]], the tornado crossed into [[Connecticut]]. The tornado knocked down numerous power lines, cutting power to about 10,000 residences in the county. In all, six people sustained minor injuries and damages amounted to $10.1 million (2006 USD). The weakening tornado ended its life in Fairfield County, Connecticut near the town of [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]]. Thousands of trees were either uprooted or snapped along the 2 mi (3.2 km) path through the state. Minor damage was also reported to several structures. The tornado left 52 residences in Greenwich without power{{cite web| author=Eyewitness News| date=2006-07-13| title=Weather Service confirms F2 tornado in area, Sleepy Hollow, Hawthorne hardest hit| publisher=ABC News| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=weather&id=4363255}} and caused $2 million (2006 USD) in damages. ==Aftermath== In the wake of the tornado, the mayor of Sleepy Hollow declared a state of emergency for the town. [[Consolidated Edison]] (conEdison) crews were sent out to repair downed power lines and clear roads. By the next night, power was restored to all but 600 of the previous 10,000 residences without power in [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]]. Westchester County opened its Emergency Operations Center after the storm to quickly respond to the event.{{cite web| author=Associated Press| date=2006-07-13| title=Westchester County Storm: Let The Clean-Up Begin| publisher=WCBS| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://wcbstv.com/topstories/Tornado.Tornado.Warning.2.236314.html}} Two days after the storm, many of the roads had been cleared and power was fully restored. A recreational path in [[Tarrytown, New York]] was not expected to be open for another two weeks due to numerous fallen trees.{{cite web| date=2006-7-15|author=Candice Ferrette| title=Westchester tornado twists many lives| publisher=Journal News| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.lohud.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060715/NEWS02/607150347}} [[Metro-North Railroad]] suspended trains on the Upper Harlem line until 5:00 p.m. EDT (21:00 UTC) for the removal of debris on the tracks. During the time the rails were shut down, southbound passengers were transported by bus. ==See also== *[[List of North American tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]] *[[Tornadoes of 2006]] *[[List of Connecticut tornadoes]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://wcbstv.com/video/?id=89570@wcbs.dayport.com Doppler Radar image of the tornadic supercell nearing Tarrytown] *[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_fLZLrZAB0M Video of the tornado damage in Westchester] *[http://wcbstv.com/topstories/Tornado.Tornado.Warning.2.236314.html WCBS article and video of damage/press reports of the tornado] [[Category:F2 tornadoes]] [[Category:New York tornadoes]] [[Category:Connecticut tornadoes]] [[Category:Tornadoes of 2006]] [[Category:2006 in the United States]]

About 15 minutes later, a [[tornado warning]] was issued for southern Rockland and [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]] counties which would remain in effect until 4:15 p.m. (21:15 UTC). At around 3:30 p.m. EDT (19:30 UTC), an [[Fujita_scale#Parameters|F1]] tornado touched down near [[Grand View-on-Hudson, New York|Grand View-on-Hudson]] along the [[Hudson River]] in [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland County]]. The 100 [[yard]] (91 [[metre|m]]) wide tornado touched down on a dock before becoming a [[waterspout]] as it took a 3 [[mile|miles]] (4.8 [[kilometre|km]]) path across the river. The tornado passed near the [[Tappan Zee Bridge]] before crossing into [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester County]].{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #626587 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626587}} The tornado hit the town of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow, New York]] around 3:37 p.m. EDT (19:37 UTC), two minutes later, a 58 mph (93 km/h) wind gust was reported along the periphery of the tornado. As the tornado neared [[New York State Route 9A]], it intensified into an F2 tornado, packing winds up to 157 mph (253 km/h), and struck the California Closet Warehouse. At this time, the tornado was estimated to be 300 yd (274 m) wide and was the strongest tornado ever recorded in Westchester County.{{cite web| author=Jim Fitzgerald| date=2006-07-14| title=Weather Service confirms F-2 tornado roared through N.Y., Conn. on Wednesday| publisher=USA Today| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.usatoday.com/weather/storms/2006-07-14-ny-tornado-confirmed_x.htm}} Shortly after, the tornado weakened back to F1 intensity. Minor damage was reported through the [[Kensico Reservoir]] in [[Valhalla, New York|Valhalla]] as the tornado neared the New York/[[Connecticut]] border. The track length through Westchester County was measured at around 8 mi (12.8 km).{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #626588 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626588}} After crossing the border into [[Fairfield County, Connecticut]], the tornado weakened further before lifting at 4:03 p.m. EDT (20:03 UTC) in [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]] after traveling 2 mi (3.2 km) in Connecticut. Six minor injuries were also reported due to the tornado. In all, the tornado caused $12.1 million (2006 [[United States Dollar|USD]]; $12.9 million 2008 USD). Minor damage was reported in Rockland County. Only one structure, a dock, and one boat were damaged by the tornado. After crossing the [[Hudson River]], the tornado entered Westchester County, where the worst of the damage took place. The tornado first struck the town of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow]], damaging roofs and tearing the siding off of numerous homes and businesses. A 10 [[foot (length)|foot]] (3 [[metre|m]]) tall stained-glass window in the St. Teresa of Avila Church was shattered. Afterwards, the town of [[Pocantico Hills, New York|Pocantico Hills]] was struck as the tornado intensified to F2 intensity. Several trees were uprooted and two barns were destroyed. The California Closet Warehouse suffered severe structural damage, having two two-story concrete wall being destroyed. An interior staircase, which employees used as a shelter, collapsed, injuring four of them. Concrete blocks from the building were thrown all over, several cars in the nearby parking lot were hit by the blocks. A nearby Comfort Inn had part of its roof torn off.{{cite web| date=2006-7-13|author=Associated Press| title=Tornado Rips Through Suburban New York| publisher=Internet Broadcasting Systems, Inc.| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.wesh.com/news/9510358/detail.html}} After a [[tornado warning]] was issued, a school close to the warehouse was evacuated.{{cite web| author=Lisa W. Foderaro| date=2006-07-13| title=Tornado in Westchester Tosses Around Trees and Damages Property| publisher=New York Times| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/13/nyregion/13weather.html?pagewanted=print}} As the tornado crossed [[New York State Route 9A]], it picked up a state trooper car and flipped it a few times before it fell to the ground; the officer inside suffered only minor injuries. Moving to the east-northeast, the tornado struck the towns of [[Mount Pleasant, New York|Mount Pleasant]] and [[Hawthorne, New York|Hawthorne]], damaging numerous trees and causing minor structural damage. Damage along the [[Saw Mill River Parkway]] led officials to shut down a section of it near Mount Pleasant.{{cite web| author= Rose Arce | date=2006-07-13| title=Tornado hits north of Manhattan, Winds damage store, close highway; no serious injuries reported| publisher=Cable News Network.| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/WEATHER/07/12/ny.tornado/index.html }} Trees fell on streets and railroad tracks, halting [[Metro-North Railroad]] service and creating major traffic delays. After passing by the [[Kensico Reservoir]] in [[Valhalla, New York|Valhalla]], the tornado crossed into [[Connecticut]]. The tornado knocked down numerous power lines, cutting power to about 10,000 residences in the county. In all, six people sustained minor injuries and damages amounted to $10.1 million (2006 USD). The weakening tornado ended its life in Fairfield County, Connecticut near the town of [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]]. Thousands of trees were either uprooted or snapped along the 2 mi (3.2 km) path through the state. Minor damage was also reported to several structures. The tornado left 52 residences in Greenwich without power{{cite web| author=Eyewitness News| date=2006-07-13| title=Weather Service confirms F2 tornado in area, Sleepy Hollow, Hawthorne hardest hit| publisher=ABC News| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=weather&id=4363255}} and caused $2 million (2006 USD) in damages. ==Aftermath== In the wake of the tornado, the mayor of Sleepy Hollow declared a state of emergency for the town. [[Consolidated Edison]] (conEdison) crews were sent out to repair downed power lines and clear roads. By the next night, power was restored to all but 600 of the previous 10,000 residences without power in [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]]. Westchester County opened its Emergency Operations Center after the storm to quickly respond to the event.{{cite web| author=Associated Press| date=2006-07-13| title=Westchester County Storm: Let The Clean-Up Begin| publisher=WCBS| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://wcbstv.com/topstories/Tornado.Tornado.Warning.2.236314.html}} Two days after the storm, many of the roads had been cleared and power was fully restored. A recreational path in [[Tarrytown, New York]] was not expected to be open for another two weeks due to numerous fallen trees.{{cite web| date=2006-7-15|author=Candice Ferrette| title=Westchester tornado twists many lives| publisher=Journal News| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.lohud.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060715/NEWS02/607150347}} [[Metro-North Railroad]] suspended trains on the Upper Harlem line until 5:00 p.m. EDT (21:00 UTC) for the removal of debris on the tracks. During the time the rails were shut down, southbound passengers were transported by bus. ==See also== *[[List of North American tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]] *[[Tornadoes of 2006]] *[[List of Connecticut tornadoes]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://wcbstv.com/video/?id=89570@wcbs.dayport.com Doppler Radar image of the tornadic supercell nearing Tarrytown] *[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_fLZLrZAB0M Video of the tornado damage in Westchester] *[http://wcbstv.com/topstories/Tornado.Tornado.Warning.2.236314.html WCBS article and video of damage/press reports of the tornado] [[Category:F2 tornadoes]] [[Category:New York tornadoes]] [[Category:Connecticut tornadoes]] [[Category:Tornadoes of 2006]] [[Category:2006 in the United States]]

At around 3:30 p.m. EDT (19:30 UTC), an [[Fujita_scale#Parameters|F1]] tornado touched down near [[Grand View-on-Hudson, New York|Grand View-on-Hudson]] along the [[Hudson River]] in [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland County]]. The 100 [[yard]] (91 [[metre|m]]) wide tornado touched down on a dock before becoming a [[waterspout]] as it took a 3 [[mile|miles]] (4.8 [[kilometre|km]]) path across the river. The tornado passed near the [[Tappan Zee Bridge]] before crossing into [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester County]].{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #626587 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626587}} The tornado hit the town of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow, New York]] around 3:37 p.m. EDT (19:37 UTC), two minutes later, a 58 mph (93 km/h) wind gust was reported along the periphery of the tornado. As the tornado neared [[New York State Route 9A]], it intensified into an F2 tornado, packing winds up to 157 mph (253 km/h), and struck the California Closet Warehouse. At this time, the tornado was estimated to be 300 yd (274 m) wide and was the strongest tornado ever recorded in Westchester County.{{cite web| author=Jim Fitzgerald| date=2006-07-14| title=Weather Service confirms F-2 tornado roared through N.Y., Conn. on Wednesday| publisher=USA Today| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.usatoday.com/weather/storms/2006-07-14-ny-tornado-confirmed_x.htm}} Shortly after, the tornado weakened back to F1 intensity. Minor damage was reported through the [[Kensico Reservoir]] in [[Valhalla, New York|Valhalla]] as the tornado neared the New York/[[Connecticut]] border. The track length through Westchester County was measured at around 8 mi (12.8 km).{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #626588 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626588}} After crossing the border into [[Fairfield County, Connecticut]], the tornado weakened further before lifting at 4:03 p.m. EDT (20:03 UTC) in [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]] after traveling 2 mi (3.2 km) in Connecticut. Another brief touchdown may have occurred shortly after near the [[Merritt Parkway]].{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #606978 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~606978}} The tornado tracked across a total of 13 mi (20.9 km) through two states over a period over 33 minutes.{{cite web| date=2006-7-14| title=Summary of Tornado| publisher=[[National Weather Service]] in Upton, New York| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/okx/pns/torjul06.txt}} ==Impact== [[Image:DCP 7760.JPG|thumb|right|Tornado damage near a forested area]] The tornado took a clear path through [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland]], [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]], and [[Fairfield County, Connecticut|Fairfield]] counties, downing or uprooting thousands of trees, and damaging several structures, including significant structural damage to the California Closest Warehouse. Six minor injuries were also reported due to the tornado. In all, the tornado caused $12.1 million (2006 [[United States Dollar|USD]]; $12.9 million 2008 USD). Minor damage was reported in Rockland County. Only one structure, a dock, and one boat were damaged by the tornado. After crossing the [[Hudson River]], the tornado entered Westchester County, where the worst of the damage took place. The tornado first struck the town of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow]], damaging roofs and tearing the siding off of numerous homes and businesses. A 10 [[foot (length)|foot]] (3 [[metre|m]]) tall stained-glass window in the St. Teresa of Avila Church was shattered. Afterwards, the town of [[Pocantico Hills, New York|Pocantico Hills]] was struck as the tornado intensified to F2 intensity. Several trees were uprooted and two barns were destroyed. The California Closet Warehouse suffered severe structural damage, having two two-story concrete wall being destroyed. An interior staircase, which employees used as a shelter, collapsed, injuring four of them. Concrete blocks from the building were thrown all over, several cars in the nearby parking lot were hit by the blocks. A nearby Comfort Inn had part of its roof torn off.{{cite web| date=2006-7-13|author=Associated Press| title=Tornado Rips Through Suburban New York| publisher=Internet Broadcasting Systems, Inc.| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.wesh.com/news/9510358/detail.html}} After a [[tornado warning]] was issued, a school close to the warehouse was evacuated.{{cite web| author=Lisa W. Foderaro| date=2006-07-13| title=Tornado in Westchester Tosses Around Trees and Damages Property| publisher=New York Times| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/13/nyregion/13weather.html?pagewanted=print}} As the tornado crossed [[New York State Route 9A]], it picked up a state trooper car and flipped it a few times before it fell to the ground; the officer inside suffered only minor injuries. Moving to the east-northeast, the tornado struck the towns of [[Mount Pleasant, New York|Mount Pleasant]] and [[Hawthorne, New York|Hawthorne]], damaging numerous trees and causing minor structural damage. Damage along the [[Saw Mill River Parkway]] led officials to shut down a section of it near Mount Pleasant.{{cite web| author= Rose Arce | date=2006-07-13| title=Tornado hits north of Manhattan, Winds damage store, close highway; no serious injuries reported| publisher=Cable News Network.| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/WEATHER/07/12/ny.tornado/index.html }} Trees fell on streets and railroad tracks, halting [[Metro-North Railroad]] service and creating major traffic delays. After passing by the [[Kensico Reservoir]] in [[Valhalla, New York|Valhalla]], the tornado crossed into [[Connecticut]]. The tornado knocked down numerous power lines, cutting power to about 10,000 residences in the county. In all, six people sustained minor injuries and damages amounted to $10.1 million (2006 USD). The weakening tornado ended its life in Fairfield County, Connecticut near the town of [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]]. Thousands of trees were either uprooted or snapped along the 2 mi (3.2 km) path through the state. Minor damage was also reported to several structures. The tornado left 52 residences in Greenwich without power{{cite web| author=Eyewitness News| date=2006-07-13| title=Weather Service confirms F2 tornado in area, Sleepy Hollow, Hawthorne hardest hit| publisher=ABC News| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=weather&id=4363255}} and caused $2 million (2006 USD) in damages. ==Aftermath== In the wake of the tornado, the mayor of Sleepy Hollow declared a state of emergency for the town. [[Consolidated Edison]] (conEdison) crews were sent out to repair downed power lines and clear roads. By the next night, power was restored to all but 600 of the previous 10,000 residences without power in [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]]. Westchester County opened its Emergency Operations Center after the storm to quickly respond to the event.{{cite web| author=Associated Press| date=2006-07-13| title=Westchester County Storm: Let The Clean-Up Begin| publisher=WCBS| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://wcbstv.com/topstories/Tornado.Tornado.Warning.2.236314.html}} Two days after the storm, many of the roads had been cleared and power was fully restored. A recreational path in [[Tarrytown, New York]] was not expected to be open for another two weeks due to numerous fallen trees.{{cite web| date=2006-7-15|author=Candice Ferrette| title=Westchester tornado twists many lives| publisher=Journal News| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.lohud.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060715/NEWS02/607150347}} [[Metro-North Railroad]] suspended trains on the Upper Harlem line until 5:00 p.m. EDT (21:00 UTC) for the removal of debris on the tracks. During the time the rails were shut down, southbound passengers were transported by bus. ==See also== *[[List of North American tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]] *[[Tornadoes of 2006]] *[[List of Connecticut tornadoes]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://wcbstv.com/video/?id=89570@wcbs.dayport.com Doppler Radar image of the tornadic supercell nearing Tarrytown] *[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_fLZLrZAB0M Video of the tornado damage in Westchester] *[http://wcbstv.com/topstories/Tornado.Tornado.Warning.2.236314.html WCBS article and video of damage/press reports of the tornado] [[Category:F2 tornadoes]] [[Category:New York tornadoes]] [[Category:Connecticut tornadoes]] [[Category:Tornadoes of 2006]] [[Category:2006 in the United States]]

About 15 minutes later, a [[tornado warning]] was issued for southern Rockland and [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]] counties which would remain in effect until 4:15 p.m. (21:15 UTC). At around 3:30 p.m. EDT (19:30 UTC), an [[Fujita_scale#Parameters|F1]] tornado touched down near [[Grand View-on-Hudson, New York|Grand View-on-Hudson]] along the [[Hudson River]] in [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland County]]. The 100 [[yard]] (91 [[metre|m]]) wide tornado touched down on a dock before becoming a [[waterspout]] as it took a 3 [[mile|miles]] (4.8 [[kilometre|km]]) path across the river. The tornado passed near the [[Tappan Zee Bridge]] before crossing into [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester County]].{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #626587 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626587}} The tornado hit the town of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow, New York]] around 3:37 p.m. EDT (19:37 UTC), two minutes later, a 58 mph (93 km/h) wind gust was reported along the periphery of the tornado. As the tornado neared [[New York State Route 9A]], it intensified into an F2 tornado, packing winds up to 157 mph (253 km/h), and struck the California Closet Warehouse. At this time, the tornado was estimated to be 300 yd (274 m) wide and was the strongest tornado ever recorded in Westchester County.{{cite web| author=Jim Fitzgerald| date=2006-07-14| title=Weather Service confirms F-2 tornado roared through N.Y., Conn. on Wednesday| publisher=USA Today| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.usatoday.com/weather/storms/2006-07-14-ny-tornado-confirmed_x.htm}} Shortly after, the tornado weakened back to F1 intensity. Minor damage was reported through the [[Kensico Reservoir]] in [[Valhalla, New York|Valhalla]] as the tornado neared the New York/[[Connecticut]] border. The track length through Westchester County was measured at around 8 mi (12.8 km).{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #626588 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626588}} After crossing the border into [[Fairfield County, Connecticut]], the tornado weakened further before lifting at 4:03 p.m. EDT (20:03 UTC) in [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]] after traveling 2 mi (3.2 km) in Connecticut. Another brief touchdown may have occurred shortly after near the [[Merritt Parkway]].{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #606978 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~606978}} The tornado tracked across a total of 13 mi (20.9 km) through two states over a period over 33 minutes.{{cite web| date=2006-7-14| title=Summary of Tornado| publisher=[[National Weather Service]] in Upton, New York| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/okx/pns/torjul06.txt}} ==Impact== [[Image:DCP 7760.JPG|thumb|right|Tornado damage near a forested area]] The tornado took a clear path through [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland]], [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]], and [[Fairfield County, Connecticut|Fairfield]] counties, downing or uprooting thousands of trees, and damaging several structures, including significant structural damage to the California Closest Warehouse. Six minor injuries were also reported due to the tornado. In all, the tornado caused $12.1 million (2006 [[United States Dollar|USD]]; $12.9 million 2008 USD). Minor damage was reported in Rockland County. Only one structure, a dock, and one boat were damaged by the tornado. After crossing the [[Hudson River]], the tornado entered Westchester County, where the worst of the damage took place. The tornado first struck the town of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow]], damaging roofs and tearing the siding off of numerous homes and businesses. A 10 [[foot (length)|foot]] (3 [[metre|m]]) tall stained-glass window in the St. Teresa of Avila Church was shattered. Afterwards, the town of [[Pocantico Hills, New York|Pocantico Hills]] was struck as the tornado intensified to F2 intensity. Several trees were uprooted and two barns were destroyed. The California Closet Warehouse suffered severe structural damage, having two two-story concrete wall being destroyed. An interior staircase, which employees used as a shelter, collapsed, injuring four of them. Concrete blocks from the building were thrown all over, several cars in the nearby parking lot were hit by the blocks. A nearby Comfort Inn had part of its roof torn off.{{cite web| date=2006-7-13|author=Associated Press| title=Tornado Rips Through Suburban New York| publisher=Internet Broadcasting Systems, Inc.| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.wesh.com/news/9510358/detail.html}} After a [[tornado warning]] was issued, a school close to the warehouse was evacuated.{{cite web| author=Lisa W. Foderaro| date=2006-07-13| title=Tornado in Westchester Tosses Around Trees and Damages Property| publisher=New York Times| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/13/nyregion/13weather.html?pagewanted=print}} As the tornado crossed [[New York State Route 9A]], it picked up a state trooper car and flipped it a few times before it fell to the ground; the officer inside suffered only minor injuries. Moving to the east-northeast, the tornado struck the towns of [[Mount Pleasant, New York|Mount Pleasant]] and [[Hawthorne, New York|Hawthorne]], damaging numerous trees and causing minor structural damage. Damage along the [[Saw Mill River Parkway]] led officials to shut down a section of it near Mount Pleasant.{{cite web| author= Rose Arce | date=2006-07-13| title=Tornado hits north of Manhattan, Winds damage store, close highway; no serious injuries reported| publisher=Cable News Network.| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/WEATHER/07/12/ny.tornado/index.html }} Trees fell on streets and railroad tracks, halting [[Metro-North Railroad]] service and creating major traffic delays. After passing by the [[Kensico Reservoir]] in [[Valhalla, New York|Valhalla]], the tornado crossed into [[Connecticut]]. The tornado knocked down numerous power lines, cutting power to about 10,000 residences in the county. In all, six people sustained minor injuries and damages amounted to $10.1 million (2006 USD). The weakening tornado ended its life in Fairfield County, Connecticut near the town of [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]]. Thousands of trees were either uprooted or snapped along the 2 mi (3.2 km) path through the state. Minor damage was also reported to several structures. The tornado left 1,700 residences in Greenwich without power and blocked six roads. Most of the damage was concentrated to the northwestern corner of the town.{{cite web| author=Avi Salzman and Anahad O'Connor| date=2006-07-16| title=The Week; Rare Tornado Snaps Trees and Power Lines| publisher=New York Times| accessdate=2008-12-01|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F04E2D91F30F935A25754C0A9609C8B63}} and caused $2 million (2006 USD) in damages. ==Aftermath== In the wake of the tornado, the mayor of Sleepy Hollow declared a state of emergency for the town.{{cite web| author=Eyewitness News| date=2006-07-13| title=Weather Service confirms F2 tornado in area, Sleepy Hollow, Hawthorne hardest hit| publisher=ABC News| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=weather&id=4363255}} [[Consolidated Edison]] (conEdison) crews were sent out to repair downed power lines and clear roads. By the next night, power was restored to all but 600 of the previous 10,000 residences without power in [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]]. Westchester County opened its Emergency Operations Center after the storm to quickly respond to the event.{{cite web| author=Associated Press| date=2006-07-13| title=Westchester County Storm: Let The Clean-Up Begin| publisher=WCBS| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://wcbstv.com/topstories/Tornado.Tornado.Warning.2.236314.html}} Two days after the storm, many of the roads had been cleared and power was fully restored. A recreational path in [[Tarrytown, New York]] was not expected to be open for another two weeks due to numerous fallen trees.{{cite web| date=2006-7-15|author=Candice Ferrette| title=Westchester tornado twists many lives| publisher=Journal News| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.lohud.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060715/NEWS02/607150347}} [[Metro-North Railroad]] suspended trains on the Upper Harlem line until 5:00 p.m. EDT (21:00 UTC) for the removal of debris on the tracks. During the time the rails were shut down, southbound passengers were transported by bus. ==See also== *[[List of North American tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]] *[[Tornadoes of 2006]] *[[List of Connecticut tornadoes]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://wcbstv.com/video/?id=89570@wcbs.dayport.com Doppler Radar image of the tornadic supercell nearing Tarrytown] *[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_fLZLrZAB0M Video of the tornado damage in Westchester] *[http://wcbstv.com/topstories/Tornado.Tornado.Warning.2.236314.html WCBS article and video of damage/press reports of the tornado] [[Category:F2 tornadoes]] [[Category:New York tornadoes]] [[Category:Connecticut tornadoes]] [[Category:Tornadoes of 2006]] [[Category:2006 in the United States]]

With conditions favorable for the development of a [[tornado]], the [[Storm Prediction Center]] issued a [[tornado watch]] was issued at 12:40 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] (16:40 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]).{{cite web| author=Thompson| date=2006-07-12| title=Severe Weather Watch #593 (Tornado Watch)| publisher=[[Storm Prediction Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/products/watch/2006/ww0593.html}} At around 1:05 p.m. EDT (17:05 UTC), a thunderstorm produced winds up to 60 [[miles per hour|mph]] (95 [[kilometres per hour|km/h]]) in [[Warren County, New Jersey|Warren County]], which snapped tree limbs and damaged power lines.{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #625642 (Thunderstorm Wind)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~625642}} A stronger thunderstorm developed around 2 p.m. EDT (18:00 UTC) and produced a [[funnel cloud]] near [[Carlstadt, New Jersey|Carlstadt]] at around 2:45 p.m. EDT (18:45 UTC), no damage was associated with the funnel.{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #625643 (Funnel Cloud)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~625643}} That same storm became stronger and developed into a supercell thunderstorm as it crossed into [[New York]]. About 15 minutes later, a [[tornado warning]] was issued for southern Rockland and [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]] counties which would remain in effect until 4:15 p.m. (21:15 UTC). At around 3:30 p.m. EDT (19:30 UTC), an [[Fujita_scale#Parameters|F1]] tornado touched down near [[Grand View-on-Hudson, New York|Grand View-on-Hudson]] along the [[Hudson River]] in [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland County]]. The 100 [[yard]] (91 [[metre|m]]) wide tornado touched down on a dock before becoming a [[waterspout]] as it took a 3 [[mile|miles]] (4.8 [[kilometre|km]]) path across the river. The tornado passed near the [[Tappan Zee Bridge]] before crossing into [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester County]].{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #626587 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626587}} The tornado hit the town of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow, New York]] around 3:37 p.m. EDT (19:37 UTC), two minutes later, a 58 mph (93 km/h) wind gust was reported along the periphery of the tornado. As the tornado neared [[New York State Route 9A]], it intensified into an F2 tornado, packing winds up to 157 mph (253 km/h), and struck the California Closet Warehouse. At this time, the tornado was estimated to be 300 yd (274 m) wide and was the strongest tornado ever recorded in Westchester County.{{cite web| author=Jim Fitzgerald| date=2006-07-14| title=Weather Service confirms F-2 tornado roared through N.Y., Conn. on Wednesday| publisher=USA Today| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.usatoday.com/weather/storms/2006-07-14-ny-tornado-confirmed_x.htm}} Shortly after, the tornado weakened back to F1 intensity. Minor damage was reported through the [[Kensico Reservoir]] in [[Valhalla, New York|Valhalla]] as the tornado neared the New York/[[Connecticut]] border. The track length through Westchester County was measured at around 8 mi (12.8 km).{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #626588 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626588}} After crossing the border into [[Fairfield County, Connecticut]], the tornado weakened further before lifting at 4:03 p.m. EDT (20:03 UTC) in [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]] after traveling 2 mi (3.2 km) in Connecticut. Another brief touchdown may have occurred shortly after near the [[Merritt Parkway]].{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #606978 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~606978}} The tornado tracked across a total of 13 mi (20.9 km) through two states over a period over 33 minutes.{{cite web| date=2006-7-14| title=Summary of Tornado| publisher=[[National Weather Service]] in Upton, New York| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/okx/pns/torjul06.txt}} ==Impact== [[Image:DCP 7760.JPG|thumb|right|Tornado damage near a forested area]] The tornado took a clear path through [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland]], [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]], and [[Fairfield County, Connecticut|Fairfield]] counties, downing or uprooting thousands of trees, and damaging several structures, including significant structural damage to the California Closest Warehouse. Six minor injuries were also reported due to the tornado. In all, the tornado caused $12.1 million (2006 [[United States Dollar|USD]]; $12.9 million 2008 USD). Minor damage was reported in Rockland County. Only one structure, a dock, and one boat were damaged by the tornado. After crossing the [[Hudson River]], the tornado entered Westchester County, where the worst of the damage took place. The tornado first struck the town of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow]], damaging roofs and tearing the siding off of numerous homes and businesses. A 10 [[foot (length)|foot]] (3 [[metre|m]]) tall stained-glass window in the St. Teresa of Avila Church was shattered. Afterwards, the town of [[Pocantico Hills, New York|Pocantico Hills]] was struck as the tornado intensified to F2 intensity. Several trees were uprooted and two barns were destroyed. The California Closet Warehouse suffered severe structural damage, having two two-story concrete wall being destroyed. An interior staircase, which employees used as a shelter, collapsed, injuring four of them. Concrete blocks from the building were thrown all over, several cars in the nearby parking lot were hit by the blocks. A nearby Comfort Inn had part of its roof torn off.{{cite web| date=2006-7-13|author=Associated Press| title=Tornado Rips Through Suburban New York| publisher=Internet Broadcasting Systems, Inc.| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.wesh.com/news/9510358/detail.html}} After a [[tornado warning]] was issued, a school close to the warehouse was evacuated.{{cite web| author=Lisa W. Foderaro| date=2006-07-13| title=Tornado in Westchester Tosses Around Trees and Damages Property| publisher=New York Times| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/13/nyregion/13weather.html?pagewanted=print}} As the tornado crossed [[New York State Route 9A]], it picked up a state trooper car and flipped it a few times before it fell to the ground; the officer inside suffered only minor injuries. Moving to the east-northeast, the tornado struck the towns of [[Mount Pleasant, New York|Mount Pleasant]] and [[Hawthorne, New York|Hawthorne]], damaging numerous trees and causing minor structural damage. Damage along the [[Saw Mill River Parkway]] led officials to shut down a section of it near Mount Pleasant.{{cite web| author= Rose Arce | date=2006-07-13| title=Tornado hits north of Manhattan, Winds damage store, close highway; no serious injuries reported| publisher=Cable News Network.| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/WEATHER/07/12/ny.tornado/index.html }} Trees fell on streets and railroad tracks, halting [[Metro-North Railroad]] service and creating major traffic delays. After passing by the [[Kensico Reservoir]] in [[Valhalla, New York|Valhalla]], the tornado crossed into [[Connecticut]]. The tornado knocked down numerous power lines, cutting power to about 10,000 residences in the county. In all, six people sustained minor injuries and damages amounted to $10.1 million (2006 USD). The weakening tornado ended its life in Fairfield County, Connecticut near the town of [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]]. Thousands of trees were either uprooted or snapped along the 2 mi (3.2 km) path through the state. Minor damage was also reported to several structures. The tornado left 1,700 residences in Greenwich without power and blocked six roads. Most of the damage was concentrated to the northwestern corner of the town.{{cite web| author=Avi Salzman and Anahad O'Connor| date=2006-07-16| title=The Week; Rare Tornado Snaps Trees and Power Lines| publisher=New York Times| accessdate=2008-12-01|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F04E2D91F30F935A25754C0A9609C8B63}} and caused $2 million (2006 USD) in damages. ==Aftermath== In the wake of the tornado, the mayor of Sleepy Hollow declared a state of emergency for the town.{{cite web| author=Eyewitness News| date=2006-07-13| title=Weather Service confirms F2 tornado in area, Sleepy Hollow, Hawthorne hardest hit| publisher=ABC News| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=weather&id=4363255}} 200 emergency personnel responded to the storm.{{cite web| author=Reka Bala and Glenn Blain| date=2006-07-13| title=Tornado slams Lower Hudson Valley| publisher=Journal News| accessdate=2008-12-01|url=http://www.lohud.com/article/20060713/NEWS09/607130345}} [[Consolidated Edison]] (conEdison) crews were sent out to repair downed power lines and clear roads. By the next night, power was restored to all but 600 of the previous 10,000 residences without power in [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]]. Westchester County opened its Emergency Operations Center after the storm to quickly respond to the event.{{cite web| author=Associated Press| date=2006-07-13| title=Westchester County Storm: Let The Clean-Up Begin| publisher=WCBS| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://wcbstv.com/topstories/Tornado.Tornado.Warning.2.236314.html}} Two days after the storm, many of the roads had been cleared and power was fully restored. A recreational path in [[Tarrytown, New York]] was not expected to be open for another two weeks due to numerous fallen trees.{{cite web| date=2006-7-15|author=Candice Ferrette| title=Westchester tornado twists many lives| publisher=Journal News| accessdate=2008-11-30|url=http://www.lohud.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060715/NEWS02/607150347}} [[Metro-North Railroad]] suspended trains on the Upper Harlem line until 5:00 p.m. EDT (21:00 UTC) for the removal of debris on the tracks. During the time the rails were shut down, southbound passengers were transported by bus. All trains were back on schedule by 7:00 p.m. EDT (23:00 UTC). ==See also== *[[List of North American tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]] *[[Tornadoes of 2006]] *[[List of Connecticut tornadoes]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://wcbstv.com/video/?id=89570@wcbs.dayport.com Doppler Radar image of the tornadic supercell nearing Tarrytown] *[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_fLZLrZAB0M Video of the tornado damage in Westchester] *[http://wcbstv.com/topstories/Tornado.Tornado.Warning.2.236314.html WCBS article and video of damage/press reports of the tornado] [[Category:F2 tornadoes]] [[Category:New York tornadoes]] [[Category:Connecticut tornadoes]] [[Category:Tornadoes of 2006]] [[Category:2006 in the United States]]

With conditions favorable for the development of a [[tornado]], the [[Storm Prediction Center]] issued a [[tornado watch]] at 12:40 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] (16:40 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]).{{cite web| author=Thompson| date=2006-07-12| title=Severe Weather Watch #593 (Tornado Watch)| publisher=[[Storm Prediction Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/products/watch/2006/ww0593.html}} At around 1:05 p.m. EDT (17:05 UTC), a thunderstorm produced winds up to 60 [[miles per hour|mph]] (95 [[kilometres per hour|km/h]]) in [[Warren County, New Jersey|Warren County]], which snapped tree limbs and damaged power lines.{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #625642 (Thunderstorm Wind)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~625642}} A stronger thunderstorm developed around 2 p.m. EDT (18:00 UTC) and produced a [[funnel cloud]] near [[Carlstadt, New Jersey|Carlstadt]] at around 2:45 p.m. EDT (18:45 UTC), no damage was associated with the funnel.{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #625643 (Funnel Cloud)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~625643}} That same storm became stronger and developed into a supercell thunderstorm as it crossed into [[New York]]. About 15 minutes later, a [[tornado warning]] was issued for southern Rockland and [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]] counties which would remain in effect until 4:15 p.m. (21:15 UTC). At around 3:30 p.m. EDT (19:30 UTC), an [[Fujita_scale#Parameters|F1]] tornado touched down near [[Grand View-on-Hudson, New York|Grand View-on-Hudson]] along the [[Hudson River]] in [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland County]]. The 100 yard (91 m) wide tornado touched down on a dock before becoming a [[waterspout]] as it took a 3 miles (4.8 km) path across the river. The tornado passed near the [[Tappan Zee Bridge]] before crossing into [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester County]].{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #626587 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626587}} The tornado hit the town of [[Sleepy Hollow, New York|Sleepy Hollow, New York]] around 3:37 p.m. EDT (19:37 UTC), two minutes later, a 58 mph (93 km/h) wind gust was reported along the periphery of the tornado. As the tornado neared [[New York State Route 9A]], it intensified into an F2 tornado, packing winds up to 157 mph (253 km/h), and struck the California Closet Warehouse. At this time, the tornado was estimated to be 300 yd (274 m) wide and was the strongest tornado ever recorded in Westchester County.{{cite web| author=Jim Fitzgerald| date=2006-07-14| title=Weather Service confirms F-2 tornado roared through N.Y., Conn. on Wednesday| publisher=USA Today| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www.usatoday.com/weather/storms/2006-07-14-ny-tornado-confirmed_x.htm}} Shortly after, the tornado weakened back to F1 intensity. Minor damage was reported through the [[Kensico Reservoir]] in [[Valhalla, New York|Valhalla]] as the tornado neared the New York/[[Connecticut]] border. The track length through Westchester County was measured at around 8 mi (12.8 km).{{cite web| author=Stuart Hinson| year=2006| title=July 12, Weather Event #626588 (Tornado)| publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]| accessdate=2008-11-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~626588}} After crossing the state border into [[Fairfield County, Connecticut]], the tornado weakened further before lifting at 4:03 p.m. EDT (20:03 UTC) in [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]] after traveling 2 mi (3.2 km) in Connecticut.
